tips.title: Real-World Tips
tips.subtitle: Top 11 tips from 11 months of intense Claude Code usage
tips.mainSubtitle: Battle-tested techniques from 11 months of intense daily usage
tips.detailDescription: These tips come from developers who've spent 11+ months using Claude Code daily, compiled from 40+ community-validated techniques.
tips.sourceCredit: Based on community tips by ykdojo

tip1.title: Minimize the Provided Context
tip1.description: The longer the given context, the worse Claude performs. AI context is like milk - it's best served fresh and condensed.

practices.freshConversation: Start a fresh conversation whenever you begin a new topic
practices.splitTasks: First conversation: find which files to edit. Second conversation: figure out how to edit them
practices.avoidOverload: Don't dump your entire codebase into context

tip1.quote: Remember, AI context is like milk; it's best served fresh and condensed.

tip2.title: Solve Problems Step by Step
tip2.description: Claude models are good at long-lasting tasks, but not perfect. They make mistakes especially when given problems that are too large.

practices.breakDown: Break your problem down into smaller steps
practices.furtherBreak: If steps are still too big, break them down further
practices.oneAtATime: Tackle one small piece at a time

tip2.quote: If a problem is too big for Claude to solve in one shot, break it down further.

tip3.title: Don't Always Jump Into Writing Code
tip3.description: AI gets a bad rep for low quality code because people primarily use it for writing code. But Claude excels at understanding, research, and planning.

practices.understand: Use Claude for understanding a codebase first
practices.research: Do research and brainstorming before coding
practices.prepare: Enough preparation before coding is key for quality

tip3.quote: Doing enough preparation before jumping into writing code is one of the essential keys for producing high quality code.

tip4.title: Master Git and GitHub with Claude
tip4.description: Let Claude handle your Git and GitHub CLI tasks. This includes committing (no manual commit messages!), branching, pulling, and pushing.

practices.autoCommit: Let Claude write commit messages for you
practices.allowPull: Allow pull automatically, but be careful with push
practices.gitBisect: Use git bisect to find exact commits that broke something
practices.ghCli: Leverage GitHub CLI for issues and PRs

tip4.warning: I personally allow pull automatically but not push, because push is riskier.

tip5.title: Verify AI Output in Multiple Ways
tip5.description: Don't blindly trust AI output. Use multiple verification methods to ensure quality.

practices.writeTests: Have Claude write tests to verify code
practices.visualGit: Use a visual Git client like GitHub Desktop to check changes quickly
practices.draftPR: Generate draft PRs to review everything before marking ready
practices.manualReview: Always do a final manual review

tip5.quote: Having it generate a draft PR is a great way to review everything before marking it ready.

tip6.title: Let AI Verify Its Own Work
tip6.description: Claude can check its own work. For research, ask it to double-check claims. For web apps, use browser automation to verify.

practices.doubleCheck: Say 'Are you sure? Can you double check?'
practices.verifyTable: Ask: 'Double check every claim and make a table of what you verified'
practices.playwright: Use Playwright MCP or /chrome for web app verification
practices.tmux: Use tmux for interactive CLI verification

tip6.claudeMdTip: For /chrome, add this to CLAUDE.md: Use read_page for element refs, use find to locate elements, click using ref not coordinates, NEVER take screenshots unless requested.

tip7.title: Set Up a Custom Status Line
tip7.description: Customize the status line at the bottom of Claude Code to show model, directory, git branch, uncommitted files, sync status, and token usage.

practices.showBranch: Show git branch and uncommitted file count
practices.tokenBar: Add visual progress bar for token usage

tip7.quote: It's really helpful for keeping an eye on your context usage and remembering what you were working on.

tip8.title: Pass Context to the Next Session
tip8.description: Instead of relying on /compact, proactively manage context with handoff documents.

practices.handoffDoc: Ask Claude to write a HANDOFF.md before starting fresh
practices.includeTrials: Document what was tried, what worked, what didn't
practices.freshStart: Start fresh conversation with just the handoff file path
practices.halfClone: Use half-clone to keep only recent conversation half

tip8.handoffPrompt: Put the rest of the plan in HANDOFF.md. Explain what you tried, what worked, what didn't, so the next agent can load just that file and continue.

tip9.title: Use Voice Input
tip9.description: Communicate much faster with voice than typing. Even with transcription mistakes, Claude understands what you mean.

practices.fasterComm: Voice is faster than typing for most people
practices.likePhoneCall: Think of it like getting on a quick phone call with a friend

tip9.quote: If you want to communicate faster, why wouldn't you get on a quick phone call? Voice is faster for the majority of people.

tip10.title: Juggle Multiple Sessions
tip10.description: When running multiple Claude Code instances, staying organized matters. Focus on 3-4 tasks max at the beginning.

practices.maxTasks: Limit to 3-4 concurrent tasks when starting out
practices.cascadeMethod: Open new tabs on the right, sweep left to right
practices.checkOldest: Go from oldest tasks to newest

tip10.quote: Whenever I start a new task, I open a new tab on the right. Then I sweep left to right, going from oldest to newest.

tip11.title: Alias 'claude' to 'c'
tip11.description: Since you'll use the terminal more with Claude Code, set up short aliases to launch things quickly.

practices.resumeFlag: c -r shows recent conversations to resume

tip11.quote: The one I use the most is c for Claude Code.

clearInstructions.title: Be Specific
clearInstructions.text: Instead of 'modify the file', say 'change useState initial value to null on line 23 of User.tsx'

incrementalDev.title: Incremental Development
incrementalDev.text: Don't try to implement everything at once. Break it into small units.

testFirst.title: Test First
testFirst.text: Writing test cases before implementing features leads to more stable code.

codeReview.title: Always Review
codeReview.text: Review Claude-generated code and ensure it matches your project's style.

tips.conclusion: Claude Code is a truly powerful tool
tips.conclusionText: These 11 tips come from real developers who've spent thousands of hours with Claude Code. Start with tip #1 (minimize context) and work your way through. The productivity gains are real.

whatAreSkills.title: What are Agent Skills?
whatAreSkills.description: A Skill is a markdown file that teaches Claude how to do something specific. Skills are model-invoked: Claude decides which Skills to use based on your request. When you ask Claude something that matches a Skill's description, Claude automatically applies it.

locations.title: Where Skills Live

hooks.title: Skills with Hooks
hooks.description: Skills can define hooks that run during the Skill's lifecycle. Hooks are scoped to the Skill and automatically cleaned up when it finishes.

multiFile.title: Multi-File Skills (Progressive Disclosure)
multiFile.description: For complex Skills, use progressive disclosure: put essential info in SKILL.md and detailed docs in separate files that Claude reads only when needed.
multiFile.tip: Keep SKILL.md under 500 lines. Scripts can be executed without loading into context.

whatAreHooks.title: What are Hooks?
whatAreHooks.description: Hooks are JavaScript functions that execute in response to specific events in Claude Code. They allow you to customize behavior, enforce policies, integrate external tools, and automate workflows.

whatAreHooks.customizableDesc: Write JavaScript to customize any behavior
whatAreHooks.policiesEnforcementDesc: Enforce team standards and security policies

preToolUse.desc: Fired before Claude uses any tool. Validate, modify, or block tool usage.
preToolUse.useCase: Use case: Security validation, file protection

postToolUse.desc: Fired after a tool completes. Process results, trigger notifications, or log actions.

userPromptSubmit.desc: Fired when user submits a prompt. Modify prompts, add context, or trigger workflows.
userPromptSubmit.useCase: Use case: Context injection, prompt enhancement

notification.desc: Fired when Claude sends a notification. Customize notification behavior.
notification.useCase: Use case: Custom alerts, team notifications

sessionStart.desc: Fired when a Claude session starts. Initialize resources or load context.
sessionStart.useCase: Use case: Session setup, environment checks

sessionEnd.desc: Fired when a session ends. Clean up resources or save session data.
sessionEnd.useCase: Use case: Cleanup, analytics, session reports

setup.desc: Triggered via --init, --init-only, or --maintenance flags. Suitable for repository setup and maintenance tasks.
setup.useCase: Use case: Environment setup, dependency checks, project initialization

subagentStop.desc: Fired when a subagent completes its work. Process results or trigger follow-up actions.
subagentStop.useCase: Use case: Result processing, task chaining, notifications

subagentStart.desc: Fired when a subagent is about to start. Monitor subagent launches or inject context.
subagentStart.useCase: Use case: Subagent monitoring, logging, context injection

permissionRequest.desc: Fired when a permission is requested. Auto-approve/deny or log permission requests.
permissionRequest.useCase: Use case: Auto-approval, permission logging, security auditing

preCompact.desc: Fired before context compaction occurs. Save important information before context is compacted.
preCompact.useCase: Use case: Context preservation, important data backup
